text:
Good, accurate, courteous and moderate response to the young girls question.

If mankind did not create the earth, has not sustained the earth, but is charged with its stewardship. At what point in human history did our egos become so engorged that we actually believe our finite actions will curve, change, thwart or influence CO2 emissions, and their questionable implications to the earths longevity.

We are but inhabitants. Should humans think about, investigate, and invest in better stewardship of the earths natural resources we use in manufacturing goods - with the emphasis on better cradle to grave planned obsolescence - resoundingly yes! 

Should mankind commit to lifting up the downtrodden in society to eradicate poverty, homelessness, deterioration of the family, broken homes, marriages, damaged children - indeed!

To pontificate a future unspecified brooding disaster attributed to CO2 emissions, amounts to the foolish endeavouring to hoodwink the masses without acknowledgement of the competing covert agenda yet fuelling the movement.

text:
Hi, Folks.
This young lady, give credit where credit is due, did remain respectful and polite BUTTTTTT, she obviously has not done much research on what she is trying to get across. 

NASA satellite photos show that the Earth is around 20% GREENER now than it was 30 years ago AND, strangely enough, a LOT of that in the areas which are producing most of the so-called 'greenhouse' gases, India and China. AND, all of this inna time when increasing levels of atmospheric CO2 are 'supposed' to be sending us all to H*&l inna hand basket.

Global temperatures have NOT risen by anywhere near even the more modest of the dire predictions from the climate alarmists and even Michael Moore has come out and stated that renewable energy sources are NOT up to the job of providing sufficient ' clean energy to be able to replace fossil fuels. 

At the moment and the best of my knowledge, ONLY nuclear energy can do that. And the 'greenies' don't want to even hear about that.

Just my 0.02.

You all have a wonderful day. Best wishes. Deas Plant.

text: Bless her. It is sad that professors are incapable of using inductive reasoning where you look at facts, leave your beliefs and assumptions on the side and apply first principles thinking to draw logical conclusions. How do you draw the conclusion that a trace gas which is 0.1% of the gases in the environment of which CO2 is only 3% of that and the man-made portion of CO2 is only 3% of that is causing global warming. What's worse is that all the data on temperature and CO2 levels going back over 550 million years shows no correlation. CO2 levels have dropped from 7000ppm to now 400ppm while temperatures have oscillated between 12°C and 21°C during that time. It is sad how teachers manipulate their students into believing their narratives.

text:
The problem with global warming "theory" is they go with the worst case scenario every time. It's a "it bleeds it leads" function of the media. The catastrophe for profit crowd feed off it and use it to get rich, they are climate grifters like Al Gore like Al Sharpton is with race relations. They never help the problem, they make it wore for profit.

If people understood how climate modeling worked, they would see the flaw inherent. They take base data from what they consider "reliable" (back to that later). Plug it into a simulator that they designed, that may have inherent flaws/bias they don't know about (or do). Then they ask the computer model to take that raw data and run it forwards, postulating on possible outcomes. They ask for 3 solutions, the least radical i.e. low end variances, the most likely and then the most unlikely but plausible. Which scenario do you think the press reports on as "scientists say!" stories? If you said plausible but not likely, give yourself a cookie. Remember, it bleeds, it leads. Nobody is going to tune in at 10pm to see a story that says "scientists say the climate it going to be a big yawner for the next 100yrs .02 F temp rise predicted."

About that reliable sources data. There is a scientific practice that says to get as close and raw a data as you can. In essence, go to the well to get the water, don't have the water brought to you. Contamination can happen, even inadvertently. So, climatologists and the weather prediction industry, over the years have been putting satellites in orbit and on site monitors to gather that data. But they don't get the data raw, they pay researchers to act as aggregators, people that gather the shear bulk of data and distill it to a recognizable form. So years ago, a honest professor noticed a problem in the data provided. He tried to get the raw data handed to him to compare his research results against. The aggregator wouldn't provide it. They hemmed and hawed about it and just never had the time. So he decided to go to the source. He got off his ass, bought plane tickets, 4 wheelers, donkeys and backpacked into these remote areas and uploaded the raw data into his own computer right from the detection devices and moved along to the next. He started to notice something startling. That starting at a certain point in time, the data provided for his research and the climatologists started to trend away from the raw data, that what was fed them was false. that there was in fact a bigger and bigger disparity between the reality and the fact data they had been fed the closer to the now you got. YIKES! Like all computer models, garbage in, garbage out. If the base data is wrong, the model can only be more wrong. 

If you want to know more specific what happened, its called the hockey stick phenomenon. A data gatherer was a "climate change/Global warming" zealot. He just "knew" that the global temps were rising and something had to be done now, that since the ends justified the means he needed to act, so he decided to "change" the data to reflect his belief. When the professor returned, he reported the discrepancy.....nothing, crickets. Nobody wanted to know why there was a difference from reality and the data they was using. So he filed a complaint and another and another, told a story about it in prominent scientific journals and Voila! a name got spit out. The guy that had been entering the fraudulent data got outed. FINALLY some of the science journals started to ask questions, he featured prominently. What was his response? " "Oh ,well" in essence. Yeah, Mr. I got caught at it, so sure I cheated, but I had to because my cause is so important that it's ok to cheat, admitted it. And? nothing. they quietly moved him to some other tenured position, didn't acknowledge the models were all wrong because of it and moved on. so all the GLOBAL WARMING! that was going on in the 80s and 90s? It wasn't. So they moved on to CLIMATE CHANGE! to continue the grift. Duh, the climate is always changing, what better sham to exploit than that.

text: The biggest problem I have with the climate fearmongers is their apparent assumption that temperatures over the last century are normal.  They're not.  We have not yet fully recovered from the last ice age.  Moreover, in the Earth's history the polar ice caps are an anomaly.  They are NOT normal.  Is it getting warmer?  Yes, a bit.  But no where near the doom and gloom predictions that morons keep spouting.  The result of that will not be tragedy.  The vegetation bands will retreat from the equator and move towards the poles.  A great deal of fertile land which is currently incapable of a heavy crop load because it has too short of a growing season will become usable.  This is all normal.  "Normal" used to include massive forests and herds of large grazers in Antarctica.  Perhaps we'll return to such a world one day.  And it'll be good.

text:
Contrary to any statement the left puts out, if it is done by a politician, it is most likely untrue. The only people you can actually trust on the issues of global warming is NOAA. Why NOAA? Because they have literally pioneered all the research behind it from the beginning.

That being said, the research conducted by NOAA has shown that there has been a significantly large amount of destruction on the ozone layer caused by the over-emission of CFCs and Carbon Dioxide. As a result the UV rays emitted by the sun penetrate the atmosphere, which affects the algae population in rivers and lakes, which in turn kills and mutates the algae causing red tides to form. Red tides, if you don't know, are concentrated bodies of water that when an organism ingests is potent enough to kill in seconds, this includes any form of carbon based life form and usually when created, fish end up dead on the shore. Obviously not something to want to swim in.

This is why it's important that you take care of your skin and make sure that before you head outside in a sunny day you wear sunscreen lotion. The effects of the damage to the atmosphere has even been shown to harshly affect truck drivers who spend a lot of time underneath the sun, even forming harsh facial deformations on one side of their faces due to prolonged exposure to the sun on a certain part of their face.

You might be asking how I know all of this, well I used to work with the satellites used to produce data that proved the correlations I just described, and the satellite I worked with was the LISCO satellite (The Long Island Sound Coastal Observational platform). The question begs, how can you repair this damage? Well we will just have to wait until electricity no longer exists, and personally I see no reason to care so long as we have an abundance of skin care protection with SPF, just my 2 cents.

text: I’m all for global warming.  Warmer temps would affect cold climates much more so than warm ones.  Cold climates don’t allow for farming and propagation of many species. text:
That is wildly inaccurate & she is not as informed those parties, irrespective of political affiliation, advocating for legislative action to reduce the human contribution to the global warming - but that surprises no one. That's what Michael Knowles does. He challenges unprepared college students and others that haven't done their research and then when they can't effectively argue for the position they're advocating for he declares victory. Have you ever seen him post a well crafted argument made by an articulate and informed person with whom he disagrees? No? That's by design. There are many tens of thousands of people in positions of authority at universities, think tanks, politicians and others that can make the case for positions with which he disagrees and you will never see them engaged in a thoughtful and intelligent debate. 
What is the harm in global warming? 1. Rising sea levels threatening the lives and domiciles of fully 2/3 of the worlds population that lives along the coasts of global land masses. 2. The release of CO2 currently frozen in the ocean, which would be a global catastrophe if enough were released, but it would/could a global extinction event. 3. Shifting weather patterns would be a veritable coin flip as to whether there would be a drought in all of North America & snow in the Mohave Desert in the long term, or just extreme examples of current weather like the worsening of hurricanes in TX and FL in the short term. 4. Loss of ice shelfs and rising sea temperatures are reducing habitats & putting pressure on life forms that are linked to the global food supply, animals and humans alike - Polar bears are losing their hunting grounds in the 
artic; as plant die off, fish leave causing seals to leave and last Polar bears starve to death. Krill are dying in the Antarctic, which then affects the entire food chain. That's just two small, but important examples and there are many more. There are probably a dozen or more other issues that global warming is affecting. Just because one nervous, young and possibly less than well prepared student can't come up with examples on the fly is no reason to dance a victory dance. Plus he's a total douche bag, and that's a scientific fact. I would think that even if I agreed with everything he said.

author: Earl Warner

text:
@Earl Warner  First of all, I apologize for being insulting. Genuinely - I resolved to not be an a@@hole online and broke my own rule.
The Permian and Triassic extinctions (especially the latter) weren't the result of Pangea coming together - Pangea was already there, and rather, started to break apart. The latest idea is this (I think): you have a super-continent and a super-plume forms beneath it (you should check this out yourself, it's really, really interesting!). The super-plume reaches the crust, which acts as a barrier, and the plume spreads out in all directions, taking the land masses with it. The crust thins out and cracks start to appear. Absolutely, there are violent eruptions - it's not a peaceful process, you don't want to be anywhere near such a thing. Over 100,000 years (in the Permian case), the lavas build up, and so does the CO2 (along with a bunch of other gases). A tipping point is reached, positive feedbacks kick in - melting permafrost, glaciers, and deep see methane ices - and then the climate shifts, fast. Seriously, check it out, they've nailed down the timelines to within thousands of years, it all fits. Furthermore, there IS no evidence for an alternative explanation. The KT extinction comes with a nice layer of iridium, so we know the dinosaurs went out with a bang. Nothing like that appears at the Permian/Triassic boundary. 
If you can point me to a source that says otherwise I'm more than happy to check it out. I'm only interested in what's true. Since the left went anti-science bonkers I'm politically homeless, so, sincerely, my mind is open.
Again, sorry for losing my temper and acting like a tool.

text:
The way I see it, we have 2 options. 
Option 1) Restructure the entire energy industry to support renewable/nuclear energy, to gradually replace the jobs and energy supply associated with the oil industry. The risk here, is that our CO2 levels don't contribute significantly to climate change, and we lost money, time, effort and jobs for nothing.
Option 2) Do nothing. The risk here, is that we do actually contribute significantly to global warming, and will damage the ecosystems, food supply, O2 supply, marine life, cause flooding, loss of land etc...

From a risk-benefit analysis, option 1 makes sense.

text: Michael is dead wrong about this. I am an Earth scientist and have been working in this field for 40 years. The challenge is not to "protect" individual animals, but to protect the habitat overall. Global warming is occurring naturally, as it has before, but this time burning fossil fuels are adding greenhouse gasses so the RATE of heating is steeper than has ever been seen. It has the potential to increase average sea (hence air) temperatures 5 degrees with concomitant rise in sea levels and increased severity of droughts, storms, fires, etc. Republicans have not even admitted that this warming is occurring much less showed a willingness to consider IF there ways to reduce it. The environment is not, as Michael says a "Left" issue. It is all of us, and all that live on the planet. Not, humans will not spontaneously die in one firey instant. But life can get pretty hellish for all. BTW Republicans, stop with the silly comments about snow storms prove the climate is not warming: it only goes to show that you don't know the difference between climate and weather.

text:
I always get them to define what they mean by "climate change". Everyone uses it in a different way. Many times they change it depending on where the debate is going. It's best to pin them down to a definition first.

Do I believe we have an effect on the climate? Yes. As do most things in nature as well as the sun and moon. Do I believe in the future predictions of climate change that they claim? text:
The global warming argument that the Left constantly put forward is a hideous scam. Here's a cheat's guide to the truth:
Climate Change is NORMAL - the Earth's weather has seasonal variations and the climate changes from time to time.
Climate Change is NOT catastrophic - nobody's going to die because of it (generally speaking).
Carbon dioxide is NOT a pollutant - it is an important part of our atmosphere, necessary for our plant life to survive.
The world is not going to end... At all. Two degrees is practically nothing.
There was research conducted on ice cores from the polar regions a few years ago. They found that the time lag between CO2 and global temperatures is around a few thousand years (at least 80,000 years), so if you buy into the Left's argument, there's simply no way to prove if they're right.
Renewable energy is ridiculous at best - inherently unreliable, very destructive to the environment and looks spectacularly ugly - 🏠 with solar panels on their roofs are uglier than a three-week-dead rotting bull carcass.
The Left's claim that 97 percent of scientists agree on this false idea being true is a blatant lie.
The Left are completely bonkers.
Whoever writes those awesome puns in the title and description deserves a raise.
author: Mile Sipka

text: This is where I part ways with guys like Shapiro and Knowles. I consider myself a 'conservative', in that I am a Constitutional Conservative. That means, I believe in the unsurpassed brilliance of the Founding Fathers, the Constitution, and the preservation of individual liberty. But I'm not a pig-headed ideologue, blindly committed to economic theory over scientific reality. Knowles comments about deer hunting are embarrassing and idiotic. Genuine environmentalism isn't about putting mankind last; it just acknowledges the precious, and irreplaceable nature of our world. If you are Christian (as I am), it means you acknowledge that Man will never rival the handiwork of God, and so we should respect it. If you are rational, and not morally blind, it means that you are able to acknowledge that we reside on a contained sphere that, although large, is still contained and is currently being devastated by a human population that numbers in the billions and keeps on rising.  No, the problem is not 'environmentalism'; that is disingenuous. The problem is the ABUSE of environmentalism by Leftists for political purposes and a tool to further their agenda of totalitarian control.

text:
@Kloko Loko  It's good to hear from such a dedicated member of the Climate Mafia - I'm guessing a junior member of one of their regular standover speech-suppression squads. First off, the petty tactic of using human biology to make an analogy towards climate change is ridiculous as it is an invalid comparison. Second, you are technically right about us being made of atoms... Trouble for you is that we are all made of CARBON atoms (unless you're an alien from Star Trek), therefore every living thing is constantly emitting and absorbing carbon all the time. To that point, "carbon neutral" is absurd as it is technically impossible to EVER be that as even when you're dead, your remains are still trading carbon with the environment. Regardless of the speed in which emissions are rising, our dear planet Earth has a very efficient regulatory system in place to keep us comfortable - the plants and 🌲 of the world. They need CO2 to survive and the more CO2 they get, the stronger they grow (have you ever checked satellite photos of our forests from space? They're literally getting greener!), ironically helping us humans survive because as they breathe in the CO2, the 🌲 create oxygen for us to survive on. While I'm all for protecting the planet we live on, the Left's climate crusade is designed purely to use the environment as a tool to enable them to take over the world and install a global socialist government.
Third, the renewable energy sources the Left champion as the world's saviour is hypocritical since the resources needed to make solar panels and those useless, ugly-ass, bird-killing wind turbines are causing much greater destruction to the Earth than coal could ever do. Not to mention that solar and wind are inherently unreliable at best. And there's no jobs in this industry so anyone spruiking employment opportunities out of the renewables industry is quite frankly shitting through their dope-stained teeth.
And lastly, considering that the Climate Mafia are a subdivision of the Socialist Left - an organisation dedicated to committing racism, bigotry and hardship while pretending to fight those very things, not to mention being responsible for the deaths of at least 100 million people (the historical death toll of socialism), I'm not going to accept a lecture from a member of that evil group.
To the people of the Left, I say this: you have no integrity, no conviction, nothing. You're just a pathetic bunch of whiny hypocrites skulking about society on an outdated lost cause.

text:
@Kloko Loko  (laughing hard at your pathetic argument) All righty then...
I took an Earth and Environmental science course back when I was in high school - back in 2002. I learnt a great deal about the environment and about how the Earth's systems worked. Back then the Left had not manifested itself into that absurd climate cult that exists today. I also did an awful lot of personal study on various science topics (I even scored highly in a science competition back in primary school so science is something that I have a deep interest in.
When did you go to school? Sometime in the late 2000s or 2010s when the Left have infiltrated schools worldwide and initiated their false narrative? I know more about how the world works than you ever could, as your belief is so wrong that it really makes me disappointed at the abysmal quality of the "education" that young people get these days. You are really an object of pity...
But to answer to your reply, consider this. Carbon neutral DOES NOT exist. Never has, never will, for the reasons I have previously mentioned. Sure, you can eat plants that are made of carbon, that sucked in the air before you ate it, but the reality is that EVERYTHING on this planet is giving off and absorbing carbon at the same time so your argument is essentially saying that "black is the opposite of white so therefore it is a type of grey". If that sounds ridiculous to you then you've caught a glimpse at how stupid YOUR argument is.
As for renewables being less destructive than coal, don't make me laugh. If you bothered to check how solar panels and wind turbines are manufactured and saw the way that making them costs the environment, then you'll see that your rebuttal of my point about the renewables being so bad is just plain ill-informed at best.
I have a very strong mind and do not get easily swayed into joining causes. I take the time to examine something and if it fits my beliefs then I'm for it.
As for you, your petty attempts at disproving me are just plain pathetic. The Left are champions of stupidly and arrogance. Even you labelling me a 'flat earther' is pathetic as you don't even know what the term really stands for (just another useless leftie term that they use to attack anyone they don't like). The Left have this weird way of discrediting anyone who disagrees with them by labelling them stupid things that only shows how ignorant the Left really are.
There is no catastrophic climate change. The world won't end by 2030, or 2130, or even 2230 (unless nuclear war or an asteroid impact occur - always a possibility). As for being brainwashed, well go look in a mirror. Many of the Left's rabid followers have been recruited by bring brainwashed. Not just that, but the reason they are against free speech is because they know their cause is bogus and by preventing anyone questioning them, they protect their cause.
BTW, the corals are actually regenerating faster than they're bleaching. And extreme weather events are getting less frequent than in previous decades. Wait until 2030 comes around and you'll see I'm right and you're wrong. Being the nice guy I am, I'll even buy you a consolation drink.

text: Well, another Patrick, Patrick Moore, PhD and past president of Greenpeace International says: “The whole climate crisis is not only Fake News, it's Fake Science."  (Mar 12, 2019)  And this Patrick is a Canadian, not a Republican.  And while the whole global climate crisis thing is not strictly a party issue, it has certainly become a political issue.  Those who say "The science is settled and we won't discuss it any further" are either narrow minded people, or poor scientists.  Science is not a goal or conclusion, but an ongoing study to gather facts and expand our knowledge.  Even Einstein got a few things wrong, and we found those errors through continuing study.  That wouldn't have happened if we'd said "The science is settled", and just accepted everything he'd said.

text:
@Sanchez King  The Frontier Centre for Public Policy's web site published a February 2011 interview, in which Ball told an anonymous interviewer that Michael E. Mann, director of the Earth System Science Center at Pennsylvania State University, "should be in the State Pen, not Penn State". 

This referred to Mann's role in the Climatic Research Unit email controversy. Mann then sued Ball and Frontier Centre for libel, and stated that he was seeking punitive damages and for the article to be removed from the web site. 

On 7 June 2019 the Frontier Centre For Public Policy published a retraction and apology and settled their part of the case with Mann.
On 21 March 2019 Tim Ball had applied to the court to dismiss the action for delay, this request was granted at a hearing on 22 August 2019, and court costs were awarded to Ball. The actual defamation claims were not judged, but instead the case was dismissed due to delay by Mann's legal team.

text:
But this highlights a problem. It is the prediction models put forth about sea level rise. At one point they were saying (gore I believe) that sea level would rise 35 feet and we haven't seen it. I grew up in Virginia Beach. Right on the ocean. I've live or visited that area for around 40 years now. Almost half of the 100 year prediction scale. You know how much the water has risen in that time? I don't either, because you can't even tell that it has even if it has. So these predictions of 12-35 foot sea level rises are likely B.S. as far as I can tell. I'd wager that they are "political" estimates. Meaning that, they are floated to the public to incite a specific reaction so that the politicians or the scientists can get something else done. So, that what they do is create a model with all the worst case scenarios built in and out pops 35; or 12'. 
When did the 100 year scale start? I know they have been saying 100 years since at least 2000. Now its 20 years later. 12' in 100 years would equal about 2.5' sea level rise already and if that happened many of our coastal cities would already be flooded. I lived in Florida, along the coast, for a few years. I'm going there on Monday. I'd wager the intercoastal waterway that I will be near will be at the same height as it was 15 years ago when I was living on it.

When you ask Knowles to stick to what he knows I must simply ask, "what do you really know?" Are you a climate scientist or are you regurgitating what some has told you is true? This sea level rise sure does seem to be a scam.

text: The problem I have seen with the debate on whether the climate on earth is warming exponentially caused by humans versus the earth goes through natural cycles and is always changing, is that the vast majority of the scientists who claim that humans cause the climate to warm and if nothing changes all of our coasts will be under water by, insert date here, are funded by the government in one way or another. I didn’t give a specific year because since the late 80s, that specific date continues to change. Once we reach the previous prediction for when our coasts will be under water or the polar caps will be ice free or we won’t be witnessing snowfall anymore, they change said date. This has happened a half dozen times now. The scientists who believe that we go through natural cycles, I’ve found not to be funded by government. Both hypothesis have not been proven, we do not know what is going on with our climate, which they fail to say when making such claims. The government funded studies also claim the sun not playing a major role in our climate. I’m no scientist by any means, but that just seems ludicrous to say given that the sun literally affects everything here on earth. To me, the sun having major affects on our weather AND climate, just seems like logical common sense. But their climate prediction models show little if no interference by the sun. This is a HUGE problem with the hypothesis of human activities being the main driver of our climate. Once the models include the sun being a bigger driver to our climate over human activity, then we will finally see the true state of our climate and what it means going forward. We have a mediocre understanding of our sun and it’s cycles, but we know more about our sun than our climate, that’s for sure.

text:
@Kerry Blackburn  This is not it.
You have also coating of tin oxide or sputtered (Process that coat  metals on surface that evaporate in vacuum, Mylar balloon is one example  of aluminum coating on plastic foil but much more thick so you can see it like is  alu. foil. mirror surface). 

In this our low e window case, coating is tin oxide or sputtered silver coating, so thin that do not reduce visible light more than 20% and is almost completely transparent for visible light but infrared radiation (heat that you feel, for example from furnace) CAN'T pass.

Those windows are used because they do not let heat radiation from your room to radiate outside and make your home warmer in the winter and also colder in summer.
They increase thermal insulation a lot.

You can't distinguish regular glass from low e glass when you see it with naked eye.

text: I’ve come across a lot of people on the right who are also quite religious and as such would presumably believe in the protection of a creator God’s creations, including his plants and animals. I can feel the difference in my lungs in a city compared to when I’m in the countryside because of the decrease in air pollution for example. This isn’t made up - it’s a health related issue caused by air pollution we have created with our vehicles. You put your face on an exhaust pipe and you’ll get poisoned - I’m hoping no one contests this or that these poisons in the air are doing us damage. I also am saddened by the amount of trees and habitats being destroyed to take resources for various industries, the mini earthquakes and instability of the land caused by fracking (particularly in small residential areas like the north of England). With the lack of these trees I would assume we’d have less oxygen in the air and, as informed by David Attenborough’s documentary an increase in rodent populations which leads to increase in disease (possibly like corona virus) which obviously damages the health of the human population. I’m not commenting to catalyse any kind of hate and have actually begun the slow process of moving from the left to the right, spurred on by these videos which I’m enjoying. But I still cannot see past the environmental issue and do not understand why if we can put money (the same money that has been used on fossil fuels, cutting trees, mass farming etc) and slowly transition it towards new forms of fuels, resources, products that seems to have less of an impact on the environment, even if we are unsure of what the impact or long term consequences will actually be - isn’t investing on the doubt worth it? Even financially speaking. It’s certainly proved lucrative for people like Tesla. Again, really wanting an answer on this, one I can get on board with, that makes sense to me. A lot of what I’ve watched on this channel has resonated with me with complete refreshing clarity but not this issue.

Spirit of land, spirit of self, of animals and gods and nations and learned nature’s law. text: Human contributions to carbon dioxide levels, absolutely, cannot affect the earth's climate. The ratio of 400 parts per million, from the outset, proves that assertion to be false. Anyone with the slightest knowledge of thermodynamics knows that a substance that makes up that small of a percentage of a system cannot affect that system any more than the percentage it holds within that system. In other words, a greenhouse gas that makes up only 0.04% of a whole cannot affect that whole by 4.0%. No substance in the universe can multiply its output affect by 10,000. Carbon dioxide is not magic.

text:
Head... trying... to .. Explode!!!
I'm so, SICK of hearing these morons talk about greenhouse gasses.
Pollution, Burning Fossil Fuels, etc - increase CO2...
Is CO2 a greenhouse gas?
Yes.... one of the LEAST effective of them.
An eRt of 3.6%.

For reference, Water vapor's eRt is over 80% (I forget the exact value)

And CO2 - is less than 5% of the greenhouse gasses by volume, where water vapor ranges from the high 70s to low 90s% Globally, depending on the time of year.

So wait... 0.036 * 5% is just 0.0018% of all greenhouse heat storage.
Water vapor at the Low ends.. 0.8 * 70% is 0.56.

So clearly we should worry more about water vapor.
So why the focus on CO2?  Is it easier to regulate?
Nope.
If all Human contribution of CO2 were removed from the equation, it would drop that 0.0018% to 0.0017352.
Less than 1 100th of a single percent.

If we simply required every facility (factory or otherwise) that produces water vapor as a bi-broduct recapture that - accomplished using essentially a modified refrigerator for every 10,000 gallons of water (as vapor) per year... and costing about the same As the refrigerator...
Would reduce that 0.56 to about 0.512.
HUNDREDS of times more change in global heat retention over eliminating ALL Human CO2 production... which is impossible to do while we exist.

So why CO2?
Because changing water vapor production IS easy.. and because there isn't a problem to solve.
They want Control, otherwise the #1 goal of every summit around Global Warming would have been aimed at reducing the scale and reach of Governments, not our actions..
Because for all the CO2 produced by manufaturing, Government activity (transports, military production, etc) produce far more.
So clearly the easiest way to scale down CO2 production would be to reduce Government.

Not increase it.

text: WAKE UP PEOPLE!!!!  There is geological evidence from ice core samples AND ground core samples that show we have had several "Ice Ages" and it's an ONGOING PROCESS!!!  The Earth warms up until the atmosphere is so thin that the vegetation burns (or a catastrophe like an asteroid, volcanic eruption, etc.) and the sun is blocked out, causing an Ice Age.  The smoke or ash then slowly dissipates, allowing the Earth to slowly warm again.The warming causes the ice to melt, fast at first, then more gradually.  The melting ice causes water vapor to collect in the air and help reform the atmosphere.  Global Warming is natural and will always happen whether we are here or not.  I am not denying that humans haven't sped it up a little with the greenhouse gasses pumped into the air, but we DO NOT CAUSE IT and IT WILL ALWAYS HAPPEN, no matter what.

text:
It seems to me that Michael likes to claim that he is on the side of 'preserving the environment' as a conceptual idea, but he's not interested in actually doing something about it. He doesn't know if there is a relationship between CO2 and increased temperatures because he's "not an expert on it". There are experts from which he could learn, but he doesn't seem to be interested in it.
He is willing to 'grant that that's possibly the case' but since he doesn't know what specific catastrophe will come, there is no point in bothering with any policy. That's like saying 'I am aware that smoking 2 packs of cigarettes a day is bad for my health, but since I don't know exactly what disease I will get, then there is no point in smoking less.'

@Kloko Loko  Sorry, just have to comment on the Australia fires (although it is a month old). Initially you said the fires were caused by lightning strikes, right? When the Elder Elk claimed it was caused by arsonists, you said, "So only 24 people are charged for how much fires? More than 10 000 fires. Go and figure it out how much is for those 24 people." I may be misunderstanding this, but it seems to me you're claiming 24 people couldn't start that many fires, while lightning strikes can. Did lightning strike 10,000 times? Or is it possible there weren't 10,000 different points that fire started from?

Also, no need to worry about CO2. The efficacy of CO2 as a greenhouse gas decreases logarithmically as its concentration rises. It other words, the more times you add CO2 the less each addition does, to the point where it becomes negligible.

text:
So, I own a very old National Geographic magazine, dated late 1930's. In it, there are two pictures of the same gorge in a far northern location. In the earliest picture, the gorge is completely empty and you see only the rock walls and floor, there's not even any snow. In the second picture (ca. the date of the magazine) the gorge is filled with a glacier. 

The realization that all the ice and snow could melt in this glacier gorge in the early 1900's and be refilled with ice and snow decades later caused me to realize that climate change/global warming is a hoax, or at best it is due to incompetent "scientists" who haven't realized yet that it is normal for there to be warming and cooling cycles.

text:
The proposed catastrophies:

Warmer temperatures -- Nearly everyone would prefer to live on a warmer planet than a colder one.  How many people go out of their way to own a 2nd home so they can "snowbird" and avoid colder weather?  Far, far more cold related deaths occur in the current climates than heat related deaths.

The end of coffee --  Of course not!  Might have to grow it in Canada in the future.  Obviously exaggerating.

Flooding -- Any "increase" in flooding is caused by more and more growth and development.  DO NOT build mere feet from the ocean.  DO NOT build right next to a river you know 100% for fact will flood someday.  We have the ability to plan and control to some extent water.  We build reservoirs, canals, drainage systems, pumps, walls, etc.  Many Pacific islands and places like Miami are experiencing more flooding, but these places are measurably SINKING.

Sea level rise -- current rates are about one foot per 100 years.  I'm not going to double everyone's taxes, take control of the government, and force every citizen in the civilized world to change their habits over one foot that even my toddler won't see in his lifetime.

Increased number and intensity of hurricanes and tornadoes -- We aren't seeing this.  We might actually be seeing a downtrend, but I won't jump to that conclusion over a small data set.

The end of snow -- Nope.  Canada and much of the USA has seen several recent winters with increased snows, not less.  Even Australia started their last winter with record snows.

The end of rain, increased droughts -- Hmm, we just aren't seeing this.  A lot of places that have been in drought went drought-free this last year.  Doh!  I live in Colorado, and we ended last season without a single acre of land being in drought.

Starvation -- Plants are our food.  They THRIVE on CO2.  They grow faster with more CO2.  They die with less CO2.  I don't see a problem here.  NASA considers 8000 ppm CO2 to be dangerous in the ISS.  Less than 100 ppm, and life on earth will die.  I see no issue with 400 ppm.

Ocean acidification -- That is 100% NOT POSSIBLE, and is just a made up scary term.  The ocean is basic, and is slightly, slightly trending toward being more neutral.  I don't remember the exact numbers without looking things up but I think the ocean is around 8.4 pH.  An acidic ocean would have to be below 7.0 pH.  Experiments with grossly multiplied CO2 levels showed the ocean has a way of fighting off pH change and would balance around 8.2 pH.

There was a fantastic point in there. That there are dozens of models, all of which are different. Although they give similar predictions, only one can possibly be right. * We know this in fact and the previous one, and it is the same answer: the models have so many variables, approximations and missing elements that they have to be "tuned" by the "scientists" using them filling in the missing information so that they agree with what the "scientist" wants them to say - which could be anything. Hence the quotes around "scientist". That is not science.

text:
I really hate this debate, and hate it even more when people fall for this crap. CO2 is not a pollutant. Yes, the amount of CO2 in our atmosphere does influence temperature, but it's a tiny fraction of climate change. Clouds have way more influence in the cooling and warming of surface temperatures than CO2 does. The problem everyone seems to ignore whether be for or against the man made climate change, which is increasing temperatures is actually good for our planet, not worse. Plants grow bigger and greener the higher the levels of CO2 are, this is settled science. We artificially increase CO2 in a closed and controlled environment so plants grow bigger and faster, it's called a greenhouse. CO2 is one of the most important things in our planet, and we're trying to eliminate it?

Just before China and India had their technological boom, our planet registered around 180 ppm of CO2 in the atmosphere. 150 ppm is the beginning of the death of plants. They've convinced us all that CO2 is evil, when it's food for plants. All life in this planet are carbon based. Plants need CO2 to produce oxygen. Why are we being told 1 or 2 degrees warmer would be catastrophic? Look at our planet, it's greener now with around 400 ppm of CO2 in the atmosphere than it was +10 years ago when we were at around 180 ppm. More CO2 is good. We could really boost up CO2 levels to 800 ppm and only get a rise of 1 degree Celsius global. 1600 ppm for a 2 Celsius increase. 3200 ppm for a 3 Celsius increase.

We've got more pressing issues than burning fossil fuels. We have incredible waste and no idea what to do with it. Plastic is an epidemic and our oceans are filled with it. But here we are, debating fairy tales and doomsday prophecies that are only being used as political strategies and marketing campaigns, and people go along with it as a way to virtue signal to the world and how good they are for caring. All bullshit.

text:
"Inconvenient Truth" had 2 primary evidences.
A graph, into which you could literally enter the Same Number repeatedly, and still get the "hockey stick" incline.

And a timeline showing historic Temperature and historic CO2 levels, lockstep.

But when he tried to get it aired in UK schools, the scientific community Sued, and he had to appear in court - testifying that he Altered that timeline.
The actual placement showed that temperature increases were Followed By CO2 increases, and that temperature decreases were Followed By CO2 reductions.

We live in a universe with a uni-directional chronology.  Time passes from cause to effect in all cases.
So if the Temperatures changed prior to the CO2 levels, they were the cause and the CO2 levels were the effect.
Not the other way around.

-CO2 is a very weak greenhouse gas, but is absolutely vital in offsetting Nitrogen from the air in Jungle environs adjacent to steep mountain ranges (the source of updrafts that feed the stratosphere)
Any reduction in CO2 levels allows more Nitrogen as gas to remain in those areas, reducing the available O2 to be carried up.

Why does this matter?
Because that is the ONLY place that photons are of the appropriate wavelengths to break the bonds in O2 allowing it to re-form as O3, aka Ozone.

text:
The ‘catastrophe’ is an environmental sword of Damocles hanging over all our heads in the form of a whole range of notional tipping points that can come to pass.  If the Arctic permafrost thaws and releases all the methane currently locked in place causing a return to a former time when temperatures were something like 20 degrees hotter, think about that one, that’s a worry that keeps climate scientists awake at night,  or consider the large amount of fresh water melt from the poles has the power to change the dynamic that drives ocean currents, just a few degrees warmer and the UK could lose the warmer ocean currents that create their pleasant weather at their relatively northern latitudes.  There’s myriad mechanisms that we really don’t want to mess with, lose the current equilibrium that we enjoy and millions of people everywhere will suffer, or are already suffering.

It’s entirely plausible that the ever increasing droughts in some places in the world are signs that this is already happening, the conflict in Syria stems from such catastrophic drought.

text:
Actually, there is NO causal correlation between CO2 and warming. There appears to be a causal correlation between warming and CO2. Which is to say that (historically speaking) as the planet warms the level of CO2 rises. If I had to guess, I'd say this appears to be due to the creation of conditions that are more conducive to life, both plants and animals. But the facts are that the graph which is usually used to show a correlation between CO2 and warming is at such a condensed scale that you can't see that the warming almost always comes first--sometimes by as much as 800 years. The alarmist played a trick on the public, by mashing the years together until you can't separate the two lines and then saying, "See! CO2 causes warming!" 

Like everything else the radicals say about Global Warming, it's a lie.

text:
Nailing the conversation starter: what policy do I need to consider crafting and for what outcome and I crafting a policy to aid/prevent? There isn't any real consensus on this. And there isn't consensus on man-made climate change because the one 97% figure thrown around was such a lie it's a reveal to anyone citing it that they have no idea what they're talking about. Is the planet warming? Absolutely. Is it warming at an alarming rate? It doesn't appear to be. Could humans cause climate shifts? It's feasible but where's the data that shows we're already influencing it? Where's the cause and effect of greenhouse gasses? And if greenhouse gasses are such a problem, why are we fostering entire plant life conservations in green houses? Don't plants thrice on carbon? And if plant life grows and carbon emissions somehow lead to upticks in temperatures, won't more plants eventually scrubs the air of the carbon? The planet is brilliantly built to neutralize itself over time. It takes a lot of time but it happens. Meanwhile, are we really worried about 2° C increased Temps over the next 200 years? Won't that just lead to warmer climate? And where would warmer climates be observed? Certainly not globally because we know the equatorial zone doesn't fluctuate from season to season like the poles do. So if the poles warm a but and melt a little ice off, is it so bad? After all, few cities are built so foolishly that a few inches up in sea levels could actually destroy anything. And even then, we'll have decades to adjust.

My point is that of Knowles': start thinking about the issue in more depth and start researching what's real and what's drummed up by fakers. Just because someone has a BA in physics doesn't mean they were an A student with success in their field. It just means they made it thru school.

text:
@Wesley  Because global temp. is about 2F higher, air have  7% more water vapor today. So possibility for floods and at some place to fall  extreme amount of rain is substantially higher.

Also at places that have dry seasons, when they last they are more intense because higher temp. extremes.

Climate change intensifies all those things, like floods, droughts and hurricanes. 
Hurricanes are more stronger because water is warmer, and hurricane extract energy from ocean water, warmer=more energy.

Also 30% of our CO2 emissions are dissolving every year in ocean water so water is more acidic every year, ocean acidification.
This have effect on living things in ocean.

The, problem with this warming is SPEED of change, it's very fast, it's 9 times faster than ice age recovery time.

Also CO2 in air is rising 40 times faster than what is normal natural fluctuation.
CO2 in air is 50% higher today than before industrial revolution and is going up about 1% per YEAR, this is extremely fast.

Ecosystems can't adapt so fast, evolution do not work that fast, so we have today much faster spices extinction than what is normal.

Climate do not CAUSE fires but when fire is starter (arson, natural cause like dry thunderstorms etc) they burn lot more land.
You have example for California, In 2019 4000 detected fires and this year almost 7000 fires but this time land burned is 30 times bigger.
Reason is extreme droughts.

Search on wikipedia what is dry thunderstorms .

What is important to notice is when you have arson fires those are mostly in rural areas and detected early and can be much more effectively put down.

When you have wild fire in wild areas far from firefighters approach and not detected early those fires can grow in size of megafires .
author: Kloko Loko

text:
@Wesley  1) I just pointed that cause of fire is not important if you have dry condition and I gave you an example of 2019 and 2020 in California "In 2019 year  4000 detected fires and this year almost 7000 fires but this time land burned is 30 times bigger."

Also you pointed that more CO2 is good because vegetation is more dense and grow faster.
That is just another problem because now you need more mitigation measures because dry more dense vegetation fire is harder to put out. So more CO2 is not good but bad to fire spreading ability.

2)"If thermal radiation emitted by the Sun can easily penetrate that layer of CO2 in the atmosphere why can’t it do likewise when emitted from the surface of the Earth."

This is not how is working! 
Sun emits LIGHT, this is not invisible thermal radiation, and when light hits the ground it transform it self to heat.
You understand?
It can go IN but it can't go OUT 😂 
Actually it can go in very easily but not so easy when it go out.

So light  go  trough atmosphere without problems and when it heats ground, ground radiate back to space and that radiation is stooped or suppressed (not reflected to earth) to radiate to space by GHGases.

When IR radiation( Infrared Radiation or thermal as you called)  from ground to space is suppressed, ground can't cool down so fast and stay warmer and if you add more GHGases (water vapor, CO2, CH4, NO2 etc) ground radiation to space is even more suppressed and it can't cool down even more and it stay even warmer.

Example:
Imagine that you have oven and constant heating electric source in that oven and say you have 2 inch of thermal insulation of that oven. 
Temp. of that oven will reach temp. that is equal of energy IN and energy OUT.
So oven heats up for example to 500F.  But if you add 1  inch more of thermal insulation now heating losses to surrounding trough that insulation is now lower and for oven to compensate this it heat up at new higher temp., for example 600F so now again energy IN is equal to energy OUT but temp. inside oven is higher this time.

Also understand this. Only reason why oven heated up is because when you putted more insulation, energy IN was HIGHER than energy OUT  and new equilibrium is reached when oven was heated to 600F so again energy IN is same as energy OUT.

Now when you know that, find term "radiative forcing" in google (it's very important in climate science)  because that term explain what is difference between two cases I just explained to you with oven example, but for our atmosphere.

For example on Moon average temp. is -23°C (-9F) and on Earth, because we have GHGases it's much warmer 15°C (59F). Why? Because moon do not have atmosphere at all so all radiation from moon surface is radiated to space without any suppression. It cool it self very fast.

You have also big problem with melting permafrost in polar region where unfrozen soil melts and decompose releasing CH4 and CO2 gas.
This is called "positive" feedback or amplifying feedback.
Just as melting ICE on arctic free up more water and water absorb much more heat from sun, so you have much faster warming of polar region than rest of the planet, what we see last 40 years much more obviously.

text:
@S R  Ok, I'll bite. I'll start off by noting that I am not fervently opposed to the creation of nuclear power plants, but I believe the solution is imperfect and temporary at best. Your first statement is extremely debatable, it's true that nuclear power plants do not emit greenhouse gasses, but radioactive fission waste is extremely dangerous. We have no long term storage solution for this nuclear waste. The more that the nuclear power industry expands, and the more facilities need to be built to contain waste, the more that price goes up. Nuclear power is also the single most catastrophe bound form of energy there is. I have no doubt that America would never let a nuclear power plant meltdown, but increased standards for building quality and security measures mean that these are upfront costs are not going to go away. The final nail in nuclear power for being a permanent solution is its nonrenewablity. The fact is that any power source that can potentially be completely consumed in under 100 years means that it is impossible for it to be sustainable. 
Green energy has a myriad of issues. It takes up lots of space, requires tons of upfront capital, and can have adverse effects on the local environments. It seems very feasible that many of these issues can be solved due to its technological immaturity. Even if they can't, I feel that they pale in terms of the long term issues presented by nuclear power.
author: Joel Milkie

text: @S R  Also if you take issue with that being too long idc.
author: Joel Milkie

text: @Joel Milkie  Nuclear waste is almost entirely recyclable in other highly concentrated plants and management systems, so the need for waste is minimal. The only reason so much waste is currently lying around outside of plants and weapons facilities is because morons continue to devalue nuclear energy. Your argument about it being catastrophe bound holds no weight if you also don’t believe that America would allow a plant to meltdown. The standards for building quality and upfront costs when taking on that task is, again, heavily politicised. All this talk about green energy in the form of wind turbines and solar panels is slowing down real and sustainable progress.

text:
@Jester123ish  No, Here is what he REALLY said (from NPR article), He spoke in 2009.
"Mr Gore, speaking at the Copenhagen climate change summit, stated the latest research showed that the Arctic could be completely ice-free in five years.

In his speech, Mr Gore told the conference: "These figures are fresh. Some of the models suggest to Dr [Wieslav] Maslowski that there is a 75 per cent chance that the entire north polar ice cap, during the summer months, could be completely ice-free within five to seven years."

However, the climatologist whose work Mr Gore was relying upon dropped the former Vice-President in the water with an icy blast.

"It's unclear to me how this figure was arrived at," Dr Maslowski said. "I would never try to estimate likelihood at anything as exact as this."
It's now 2021 and the northern ice sheet is larger than it was then.  This is from the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC) 2009 "Arctic sea ice extent averaged over November 2009 was 10.26 million square kilometers (3.96 million square miles)."  And again in 2021  "Arctic sea ice extent averaged for March 2021 was 14.64 million square kilometers (5.65 million square miles)."   That's about a 40% INCREASE.  Jester, I know you wont relent on what you "know" to be, but you should.
Look up "global temp data for past 500,000 years" and look at the graphs.  You'll see that about every 130k to 160k years there is a spike in temps, some as high as 8 deg higher than we are now, all with no humans or SUV's, which means that we are currently due for an increase whether or not humans even exist.  
Lastly, until someone can tell us what the IDEAL AND NECESSARY temperature is that we must all shoot for then what is all this really about? How will we know when we have succeeded? Why is the "solution" to give up more money and more freedom?  ALWAYS, its never, ever, the other way around.

text:
@Daniel R  - The papers date to the 80's but Al Gore popularized  the movement.  

And conservatives say the climate has always changed because it has.  There has been less than 2 degrees farenheit of increase over the last 100 years.  From what I've read,  most scientists agree that part of that increase is due to humans, but I haven't seen anything on what percentage humans have to do with the increase. Basically,  even without humans the climate would've warmed on its own.  So we have a percentage in 1.8 degree increase over a 100 year period.  Given that companies are already trying to create alternative sources of energy,  we only have a finite amount of gas, and  technology is always advancing,  there really isn't a need for the amount of concern liberals have shown here.
author: ivan calkins

text: @Daniel R  - It's not difficult to infer.  If humans are partly to blame for the increase in  temperature, that would mean the planet is the other reason. It's not that difficult.  And you asked "how much?" That's my point exactly,  no one knows.  So if you can't tell me how much humans are to blame,  then there's no need for the fear mongering.  The planet has gone through heating and cooling cycles since its had an atmosphere; who was to blame for them?  And comparing the planet to a human is a false equivalence. The planet can't get sick.  Did you know at one point in the planet's history there wasn't any life as we know it.  No trees,  no animals,  no insects.  So the planet went from having no life to what we see today.  There is far more empirical evidence to suggest we can't hurt the planet than there is to suggest otherwise.  More species have already died than currently exist today.  Life adapts.
author: ivan calkins

text:
@Daniel R  - It is a false equivalence because the planet cannot get sick.  Just because a species dies (exactly why I stated the fact that more species have died than currently live on the planet)  doesn't mean the planet is sick.

From   https://climate-nasa-gov.cdn.ampproject.org/v/s/climate.nasa.gov/evidence.amp?amp_js_v=a2&amp_gsa=1&usqp=mq331AQCKAE%3D#aoh=15729691080917&referrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com&amp_tf=From%20%251%24s&ampshare=https%3A%2F%2Fclimate.nasa.gov%2Fevidence

  The Earth's climate has changed throughout history. Just in the last 650,000 years there have been seven cycles of glacial advance and retreat, with the abrupt end of the last ice age about 7,000 years ago marking the beginning of the modern climate era — and of human civilization.

Everytime the climate changes some animals die and some animals thrive. That's how life on this planet works.  The planet isn't getting sick when the climate changes,  like now.  

Basically,  this all boils down to a single truth.  The climate will almost assuredly change with or without humans. When different things are entered into an ecosystem,  that ecosystem adapts.  You can try to cite small examples all you want but the ecosystem of the entire planet has always adapted. Furthermore,  damn near every single scientific forecast about the climate has up until now been wrong.  

These are from Earth Day in 1970:
1. Harvard biologist George Wald estimated that “civilization will end within 15 or 30 years unless immediate action is taken against problems facing mankind.”
2. “We are in an environmental crisis which threatens the survival of this nation, and of the world as a suitable place of human habitation,” wrote Washington University biologist Barry Commoner in the Earth Day issue of the scholarly journal Environment.
3. The day after the first Earth Day, the New York Times editorial page warned, “Man must stop pollution and conserve his resources, not merely to enhance existence but to save the race from intolerable deterioration and possible extinction.”
4. “Population will inevitably and completely outstrip whatever small increases in food supplies we make,” Paul Ehrlich confidently declared in the April 1970 issue of Mademoiselle. “The death rate will increase until at least 100-200 million people per year will be starving to death during the next ten years.”
5. “Most of the people who are going to die in the greatest cataclysm in the history of man have already been born,” wrote Paul Ehrlich in a 1969 essay titled “Eco-Catastrophe! “By…[1975] some experts feel that food shortages will have escalated the present level of world hunger and starvation into famines of unbelievable proportions. Other experts, more optimistic, think the ultimate food-population collision will not occur until the decade of the 1980s.”
6. Ehrlich sketched out his most alarmist scenario for the 1970 Earth Day issue of The Progressive, assuring readers that between 1980 and 1989, some 4 billion people, including 65 million Americans, would perish in the “Great Die-Off.”
7. “It is already too late to avoid mass starvation,” declared Denis Hayes, the chief organizer for Earth Day, in the Spring 1970 issue of The Living Wilderness.
8. Peter Gunter, a North Texas State University professor, wrote in 1970, “Demographers agree almost unanimously on the following grim timetable: by 1975 widespread famines will begin in India; these will spread by 1990 to include all of India, Pakistan, China and the Near East, Africa. By the year 2000, or conceivably sooner, South and Central America will exist under famine conditions….By the year 2000, thirty years from now, the entire world, with the exception of Western Europe, North America, and Australia, will be in famine.”
9. In January 1970, Life reported, “Scientists have solid experimental and theoretical evidence to support…the following predictions: In a decade, urban dwellers will have to wear gas masks to survive air pollution…by 1985 air pollution will have reduced the amount of sunlight reaching earth by one half….”
10. Ecologist Kenneth Watt told Time that, “At the present rate of nitrogen buildup, it’s only a matter of time before light will be filtered out of the atmosphere and none of our land will be usable.”
11. Barry Commoner predicted that decaying organic pollutants would use up all of the oxygen in America’s rivers, causing freshwater fish to suffocate.
12. Paul Ehrlich chimed in, predicting in 1970 that “air pollution…is certainly going to take hundreds of thousands of lives in the next few years alone.” Ehrlich sketched a scenario in which 200,000 Americans would die in 1973 during “smog disasters” in New York and Los Angeles.
13. Paul Ehrlich warned in the May 1970 issue of Audubon that DDT and other chlorinated hydrocarbons “may have substantially reduced the life expectancy of people born since 1945.” Ehrlich warned that Americans born since 1946…now had a life expectancy of only 49 years, and he predicted that if current patterns continued this expectancy would reach 42 years by 1980, when it might level out. (Note: According to the most recent CDC report, life expectancy in the US is 78.8 years).
14. Ecologist Kenneth Watt declared, “By the year 2000, if present trends continue, we will be using up crude oil at such a rate…that there won’t be any more crude oil. You’ll drive up to the pump and say, `Fill ‘er up, buddy,’ and he’ll say, `I am very sorry, there isn’t any.'”
15. Harrison Brown, a scientist at the National Academy of Sciences, published a chart in Scientific American that looked at metal reserves and estimated the humanity would totally run out of copper shortly after 2000. Lead, zinc, tin, gold, and silver would be gone before 1990.
16. Sen. Gaylord Nelson wrote in Look that, “Dr. S. Dillon Ripley, secretary of the Smithsonian Institute, believes that in 25 years, somewhere between 75 and 80 percent of all the species of living animals will be extinct.”
17. In 1975, Paul Ehrlich predicted that “since more than nine-tenths of the original tropical rainforests will be removed in most areas within the next 30 years or so, it is expected that half of the organisms in these areas will vanish with it.”
18. Kenneth Watt warned about a pending Ice Age in a speech. “The world has been chilling sharply for about twenty years,” he declared. “If present trends continue, the world will be about four degrees colder for the global mean temperature in 1990, but eleven degrees colder in the year 2000. This is about twice what it would take to put us into an ice age.”

 Let’s keep those spectacularly wrong predictions from the first Earth Day 1970 in mind when we’re bombarded in the next few days with media hype, and claims like this from the Earth Day website:

Global sea levels are rising at an alarmingly fast rate — 6.7 inches in the last century alone and going higher. Surface temperatures are setting new heat records about each year. The ice sheets continue to decline, glaciers are in retreat globally, and our oceans are more acidic than ever. We could go on…which is a whole other problem.
The majority of scientists are in agreement that human contributions to the greenhouse effect are the root cause. Essentially, gases in the atmosphere – such as methane and CO2 – trap heat and block it from escaping our planet.
So what happens next? More droughts and heat waves, which can have devastating effects on the poorest countries and communities. Hurricanes will intensify and occur more frequently. Sea levels could rise up to four feet by 2100 – and that’s a conservative estimate among experts.

Here's a good one: 

https://cei.org/blog/wrong-again-50-years-failed-eco-pocalyptic-predictions
author: ivan calkins

text:
@Daniel R  - "While global warming has been trumpeted as an epic climate change crisis with human-produced CO2, a trace atmospheric “greenhouse gas” branded as a primary culprit and endangering “pollutant,” remember that throughout earlier periods of Earth’s history CO2 levels have been between four and eighteen times higher than now, with temperature changes preceding, not following atmospheric CO2 changes. Has there been “recent” warming? Yes, the global climate has definitely warmed since the Little Ice Age (about 1400-1700 AD), and it will likely continue to warm for another 200-300 years, in fits and starts, towards a max temp roughly matching that of the Medieval Warm Period. That time followed a colder period before the founding of Rome between about 750 BC to 200 BC … Although temperatures have been generally mild over the past 500 years, we should remember that significant fluctuations are normal."

University of Houston professor Larry Bell, the founder and director of  the Sasakawa International Center for Space Architecture, wrote in Forbes...
author: ivan calkins

text:
@Daniel R  -
https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms14845

The actual evolution of Earth’s temperature through geological time is a subject of considerable debate (for example, ref. 12), yet there is a longstanding view that, despite the increase in solar output, Earth’s surface temperature was, for much of geological time, warmer, not colder, than today (for example, refs 13, 14). This apparent inconsistency is known as the ‘Faint Young Sun’ paradox and to reconcile the observation of a relatively stable climate in the face of increasing solar output through time requires a parallel change in some other factors that influence Earth’s radiative budget. 


Our new compilation and probabilistic treatment reveals that for the last ∼420 Myrs, CO2, on the whole, has been elevated compared to pre-industrial values (278 p.p.m.). The highest CO2 values of ∼2,000 p.p.m. were reached during the Devonian (∼400 Myrs ago) and Triassic (220–200 Myrs ago), with individual estimates ranging up to a maximum of ∼3,700±1,600 p.p.m. at 215 Myrs. In contrast, values close to pre-industrial are found during much of the Carboniferous (∼300 Myrs ago) and late Cretaceous (∼80 Myrs ago). A linear fit to either the entire CO2 compilation, or a resampling of our LOESS fit to reflect the original data density, reveals that long-term average CO2 has declined over the last 420 Myrs by ∼3.4 p.p.m. per Myrs (Fig. 1).

Couple of things here.  One,  all of this is debated by scientists themselves,  meaning no one really knows or can prove anything when it comes to climate change.  Two,  if you are to believe the information currently out there,  the CO2 in this planet has been magnitudes higher than it currently is today.  If that is indeed the case,  that should prove to you that artificially raising the CO2 levels will not cause permanent damage, or at least history shows that it hasn't.

text:
As much as I like the Daily Wire and Mr. Knowles, you can’t deny that there is an overwhelming consensus of scientists on this topic.  This is often ignored and cited as alarmism.  His characterization of there being some global models and some say up and some say down is disingenuous.  By far and away the majority of them all say that it’s going up.  He finally gets back to the correct question when asking what kinds of policies can we craft to prevent something,  but says to prevent what catastrophe?  The catastrophe is the effect the temp changes have on economies, almost all bad and costly... and rising sea levels in places that have large and small communities and countries affected by this.  Not even really talking about the current effect it is having on small island nations like Micronesia, but cities like Miami that are already having to spend millions of dollars on the problems that rising sea levels present.  
There is also the potential for global conflict over resources newly exposed by the melting of glaciers.  Greenland and the regions surrounding are already seeing crazy amounts of posturing and fore play of the militaries of the bad actors, China and Russia.  
So then the final question now isn’t is it happening, of course it is.  I’m the final question is are we the main cause and would action upon this be a good thing.  Again, most evidence and consensus among climate scientists is yes to the first point, and the second question has an answer similar to Mr. Knowles, which is I don’t know.  That doesn’t mean you abandon all to this cause nor does it mean dismiss it because it is a hard thing to fix.

text:
Over 30,000 scientists say 'Catastrophic Man-Made Global Warming' is a complete hoax and science lie.

Wednesday, August 31, 2016 by: Daniel Barker

The highly-politicized climate change debate rages on as we approach the crucial 2016 U.S. presidential election, despite an ever-growing body of evidence revealing the fact that "catastrophic man-made global warming" is nothing more than an elaborate hoax.
And the November election may prove to be a victory for the hoaxers, according to experts who happen to be among those who dare to challenge the spurious climate change narrative.
One of these experts is Weather Channel founder John Coleman, who is now warning that the election could prove to be a "tipping point" in favor of people like Al Gore, who continue to amass vast fortunes based on the global warming scam.
In a recent interview with Climate Depot, Coleman said:
"Al Gore may emerge from the shadows to declare victory in the 'global warming' debate if Hillary Clinton moves into the White House. Yes, if that happens and the new climate regulations become the law of the land, they will be next to impossible to overturn
  for four to eight years."
Climate change proponents remain undeterred in their mission, ignoring numerous recent scientific findings indicating that there has been no warming trend at all for nearly two decades.
Al Gore's dire predictions of the melting of polar ice on a massive scale have proved to be completely false. In fact, in 2014 - a year that was touted as being "the hottest ever" in the Earth's history - there were record amounts of ice reported in Antarctica, an increase in Arctic ice, and record snowfalls across the globe.
Debunking the "97 percent" lie
On top of those "inconvenient truths," the White House's assertion that 97 percent of scientists agree that global warming is real has been completely debunked. Several independently-researched examinations of the literature used to support the "97 percent" statement found that the conclusions were cherry-picked and misleading.
More objective surveys have revealed that there is a far greater diversity of opinion among scientists than the global warming crowd would like for you to believe.
From the National Review:
"A 2008 survey by two German scientists, Dennis Bray and Hans von Storch, found that a significant number of scientists were skeptical of the ability of existing global climate models to accurately predict global temperatures, precipitation, sea-level changes, or extreme weather events even over a decade; they were far more skeptical as the time horizon increased."
Other mainstream news sources besides the National Review have also been courageous enough to speak out against the global warming propaganda - even the Wall Street Journal published an op-ed piece in 2015 challenging the Anthropogenic Global Warming (AGW) pseudoscience being promulgated by global warming proponents.
And, of course, there are the more than 31,000 American scientists (to date) who have signed a petition challenging the climate change narrative and 9,029 of them hold PhDs in their respective fields. But hey, Al Gore and his cronies have also ignored that inconvenient truth, as well.
       Many of those scientists who signed the petition were likely encouraged to speak out in favor of the truth after retired senior NASA atmospheric scientist John L. Casey revealed that solar cycles are largely responsible for warming periods on Earth - not human activity.
Al Gore and cronies continue getting richer from the global warming hoax
 But the global warming crowd continues to push their agenda on the public while lining their pockets in the process. If you're still inclined to believe what Al Gore has to say about global warming, please consider the fact that since he embarked on his crusade, his wealth has grown from $2 million in 2001 to $100 million in 2016 - largely due to investments in fake "green tech" companies and the effective embezzlement of numerous grants and loans.
You might want to take all of this information into serious consideration before casting your vote in the November election.

text:
What you need to prevent is ocean temperature and acidity increase, sea level increase and glaciers disappearing and rain patterns changing. Why? Because ocean acidity and temperature change harms the ecosystem. Because most of human population lives on the coast. Because rivers like the Ganges in India is fed by glaciers and rainfall, which isnt coming as it was and the river in summers is already drying up to rather critical levels, and its not the only such river, its one of many upon which hundreds of millions of people all over the world rely for survival and food production.
The "I like to hunt deer and eat it for diner" argument is just plainly avoiding the question and issue. CO2 inst just "possibly" a greenhouse has, it is objectively one. The carbon we release doesnt disappear anywhere. Sure climate is always changing, the problem is the rate at which it is changing and how it affects the ecosystem. Our own survival depends on it being stable and us being able to adjust to the rate its changing. Right now we cant do that. The sea is rising by a few mm every year and the rate is accelerating, thats an objective fact, its measurable. Denying it because the complexity of climate make accurate prediction problematic doesnt help anyone. It wont be good for us regardless which model ends up being more accurate.
Is human activity the cause of global warming? No. There is indeed nothing that would suggest that we are. But its incredibly ignorant and hypocritical to dismiss human activity as a contributing factor. No one would give a shit if we could keep up with the change. The issue is - we cant! Denying it because your personal life is comfortable and your subjective belief in a heavily edited bronze age fairy tale doesnt change objective reality, it just makes you look incredibly sheltered and ignorant on what the world actually looks like beyond your 4 walls.

text:
Unfortunately, Mr. Knowles is way out of his expertise on this one.  The "myriad" of studies since the 1970's have ALWAYS overwhelmingly predicted AGW.  From -
https://skeptoid.com/episodes/4487
"One gauge of the spread of the uncertainty of the 1970s was a 2008 study in the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society titled The Myth of the 1970s Global Cooling Scientific Consensus. It was a survey of climate articles published between 1965 and 1979 in the scientific literature, rather than of those published in the mass media. The authors found that 10% of the articles did indeed predict cooling, 28% found the data insufficient to make a prediction either way, and 62% predicted global warming. In other words, 90% of climate articles in scientific journals in the 1970s did not conclude the Earth was cooling. Pretty much the opposite of how it was portrayed in the popular mass media, which shouldn't surprise anyone whose profession is science communication."

And that was just the start of research into the subject.  Since then, our information, understanding and overall knowledge has expanded greatly.  And I hope you can guess what those studies have confirmed -
https://www.zmescience.com/science/news-science/climate-change-consensus-07042018/

Also, FYI oil companies, such as Exxon, have produced their own research that also overwhelmingly supports AGW, but have kept such information hidden.  From -
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/22/opinion/exxon-climate-change-.html
"In short, Exxon Mobil contributed quietly to climate science and loudly to raising doubts about it. We found that, accounting for reasonable doubt given the state of the science at the time of each document, roughly 80 percent of the company’s academic and internal papers acknowledged that climate change is real and human-caused. But 81 percent of their climate change advertorials in one way or another expressed doubt."

So, as Mr. Knowles is a man who purportedly advocates science, it is unfortunate that he has adopted a somewhat willful ignorance of the subject.
