text: One thing is certain. Temperature LEADS increases of CO2, proven over hundreds of thousands of years of ocean sediment and ice cores. After temperature increases then there will be an increase in CO2 . Sometimes it takes decades or even centuries for it to manifest. Conversely, after temperature decreases, there will then be a decrease in CO2.  In other words, adding CO2 into our atmosphere has NEVER in hundreds of thousands or even millions of years caused a temperature increase. As well as should plants eat so much CO2 that a lowering in the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere results will NOT cause a temperature decrease. It's just one of those plain ole facts liberals hate so much. "Global Warming" or (now that there is no global warming ) "climate change" has always and forever since the formation of the earth been part of the overall atmospheric condition. The sun is the main driver of climate on earth. We have a NON-circular orbit, we have a axial precession, and we have an axial "tilt" that all change , at fairly predictable times, that cause the climate change, and there is exactly not one goddamn thing we can do about it but prepare for the change. By the way, we are overdue by a few hundreds years for a cooling time. Cooler climate is bad for humans and civilization. Warming periods are good for humans and civilizations. Mainly, it is an issue of food. Can't grow food in the cold. One of the first indicators of a cooling earth is the very upper atmosphere...the ionosphere and stratosphere....and its temperature. We have seen a cooling in the upper atmosphere. This WILL lead to a cooler earth.Kinda like gravity...drop a rock, it WILL fall. WHY? well we really do not understand why there is this attraction between masses, but we know there is, and it is predictable. Same with upper atmosphere temperature changes. All this isn't controversial...just plain ole ordinary mainstream science...but the Left has seen this climate thing as an opportunity to take your money and take power. It is a con job. They INTEND to fuck you over with this...scare children, tell lies...all to control the economy ,take your money, and get power......the bastards. The vile despicable nasty terrible bastards. Just another point of fact.; we are in a CO2 deficit, with respect to the needs of plants. Plants means food. Never ever forget that. No plants, no food. No way. No how.I am NOT proposing we shit in our streets like San Francisco, or poison our water, like Flint Michigan. I am saying let's keep our land, water and air clean, prepare for living in a much much cooler climate and do NOT give these commie liberal bastards another dime and absolutely do NOT let them empower themselves anymore through this "climate hoax".

text:
Firstly, conservatives are not for "conserving" the environment.  They're for conserving the rights of individuals to do as much as they possibly can without limitations.  They want the freedom to have their way.  This is demonstrated by the constant push from conservatives to reduce as much as possible the powers of the government, and to place the power in individuals hands.  That sounds very righteous on paper, and in many ways it actually is, but when it comes to conservation of the nature, it is devastating.

Secondly, it's always hilarious to see people praise a man who can easily discredit a young student who is not well-studied on the topic she's addressing.  Have a discussion with someone who actually studies climate science, who actually knows the facts.  He claims temperature has only increased 0.2 degrees in the past 100 years....Someone who actually knew what they were talking about would call him out for his misinformation.  Temperature has increased 0.2 degrees C EVERY DECADE for the last 40 years.


What catastrophe should we plan to avoid?  We are already seeing catastrophe.  Coral reef coverage in the Caribbean has declined by 80% in the last decades.  As oceans warm at too high a pace for the corals to adapt to, they bleach and die.  As CO2 is absorbed into the ocean, acidifying it, corals struggle to produce the skeletons that allow them to grow.  As land ice melts and increases sea level, corals struggle more and more to get the light they need to photosynthesize.  


We are in the catastrophe right now.  It's not about avoiding it.  It's about mitigating and reversing what's already been done.

text:
"Our lovely blue planet, the Earth, is the only home we know.  Venus is too hot.  Mars is too cold.  But the Earth is just right, a heaven for humans.  After all, we evolved here.  But our congenial climate may be unstable.  We are perturbing our poor planet in serious and contradictory ways.  Is there any danger of driving the environment of the Earth toward the planetary hell of Venus or the global ice age of Mars ?  The simple answer is that nobody knows.  The study of the global climate, the comparison of the Earth with other worlds, are subjects in their earliest stages of development.  They are fields that are poorly and grudgingly funded.  In our ignorance, we continue to push and pull, to pollute the atmosphere and brighten the land, oblivious of the fact that the long term consequences are largely unknown .

A few million years ago, when human beings first evolved on Earth, it was already middle-aged, 4.6 billion years along from the catastrophes and impetuosities of its youth.  But we humans now represent a new and perhaps decisive factor.  Our intelligence and our technology have given us the power to affect the climate.  How will we use this power ?  Are we willing to tolerate ignorance and complacency in matters that affect the entire human family ?  Do we value short-term advantages above the welfare of the Earth ?  
Or will we think on longer time scales, with concern for our children and our grandchildren, to understand and protect the complex life-support systems of our planet ?  The Earth is a tiny and fragile world.  It needs to be cherished . "

Excerpt from Cosmos, Video # 4

Carl Sagan

text:
An eloquent defense of misstated or misunderstood objective facts. The average global temperature has risen much more than .2 degrees in the past 100 years. The "hockey stick" graph has not been shown to be a fraud, merely a victim of distorted interpretation. Whatever the motivation for both sides, the use of science (which is a method, not a religion) is the only way to determine the true facts. Micheal Knowles is an excellent debater, as is Ben Shapiro. Being an excellent debater does not require objective facts, only convincing rhetoric. One technique is to pile on assertion after assertion and not allow the listener to absorb the essence, and test the veracity of the assertions. Yes, the global climate has varied greatly over time. This change that is taking place currently is the first to be influenced by mankind. Other dramatic shifts in climate have been caused by natural events. Rapid shifts have been caused by massive asteroid strikes or clusters of volcanic activity or more slowly by orbital shifts, i.e., Milankovitch cycles. If one first understands the principles of the Greenhouse effect, which make our planet habitable, one can appreciate that if the percentage concentration CO2 (which is only a trace gas) doubles, why would it not have a strong influence on the global temperature and influence the climate?
In our system of setting public policy, of course politics will play a major role and many people on both sides have a lot to personally gain or lose. Strawmaning and ad hominem attacks is a disservice to us all. Name calling is a tactic that is best left to the grammar schoolyard and to underdeveloped minds.

"Show me the catastrophe" Ok then, where to begin? 
1. The world's ocean ARE rising already and coastal regions are not at risk, they are guaranteed to be flooded. Areas of Mexico and Miami are already suffering flooding from high tides, This is caused by severe ice loss in the Arctic and Greenland. 
2. Wildfires are already breaking out around the world, California is most famous right now, As is Siberia. Even in the UK and Australia. This trend will continue and become worse. 
3. Category 5 hurricanes are making themselves known and are more frequent now even happening out of season, Soon we see some the first ever Cat 6 hurricanes. 
4. Sustained prolonged heat waves across EU, Asia and the Middle East are already happening, India and Pakistan are hitting 55.c / 131.f for weeks at a time last year and already this year. 
5. The jetstream that divides warm south air from frigid north air around the Arctic Circle is no longer uniform, it's becoming wavey and it is stalling which is drawing up hot air over the Arctic making the ice melt faster with air temps reaching 9.c when it should be more like -5.c to -2.c, and pushing the "polar vortex" over the USA, didn't you wonder why it's called the polar vortex? It's supposed to be over the pole not the US. 
6. We are having unseasonable erratic weather patterns and cold snaps in spring, esp prevalent in the EU which decimating crops. Again caused by the Jet stream stalling. 
7. Unprecedented flooding in many parts of the world, most famously right now the mid-US with dams and levees bursting at the sheer amount of water. 
8. perversely other parts of the world are suffering decades long droughts leading to famine, disease, civil unrest and wars.
9. The heating has turned the Siberian Permafrost into PermaThaw. It is melting and thawing out at a breakneck pace so fast that scientists trying to monitor the speed of melt are losing their equipment as it sinks into what was solid frozen soil now become deep slush in a matter of weeks. This thaw is releasing gigatons of Methane which is 20+ times more potent than CO2 at trapping heat. Also Arctic ocean methane clathrates are melting due to sea temp increases which is releasing even more CH4. This is also being repeated at 7000 other lakes, seas and rivers around the world!
10. Oceanic Anoxic dead zones are forming around the worlds oceans, this is massive pockets of ocean devoid of oxygen due to bacterial interactions with increased Ocean CO2 levels. These zones are getting bigger every single day and account for several fish die offs in recent years. 
11. Oceanic acid levels are also increasing due to CO2 forming carbonic acid in water. This is deadly to phytoplankton and coral and also fish. 

Man I could go on like this for some time. Just understand this; climate change IS REAL, it IS HAPPENING RIGHT NOW. And yes! YOU ARE TO BLAME!

text:
Are green house gases driving temp, or is temp driving green house gases??  This premise has yet to be proven and is the foundation of modern climate change assertions.
More accurately: 
Fact 1) Temps on earth are largely a function of solar activity.  
Fact 2) The single largest source of CO2 on the planet is the ocean.  
Fact 3) A single degree temp change on earth will either trigger a mass absorption or mass release of dissolved gases.
Fact 4) Increased CO2 leads to higher plant growth which leads to greater oxygen production, which would simply balance out again.


Climate change alarmism is nothing but a control tactic to make some rich and give others control over the masses.  I mean, look at methane.  It's a far worse greenhouse gas than CO2, but can you control people's daily lives by regulating the crap out of methane?  No.  But focusing on fossil fuels allows you to affect people's electricity, their transportation, etc.  And if you control those, you control much about the person.

text:
@Joe Murdoch  - as a political actor he's good at avoiding a committed answer. When directly asked, "does climate change exist?" he responds by acknowledging historic patterns and then marginalizes the degree of change as it relates to temperature. Climate change is more than temperature. For example, CO2 makes ocean water more acidic.

I am not an alarmist in that I acknowledge predictive models produce varied conclusions and that the degree of change is less severe than environmentalists report.

He was specifically asked about environmental policy and couldn't come up with a simple recommendation. Regardless of his opinion on climate change there are plenty of moderate solutions available to improve water and air quality, combat erosion, and to become more sustainable.

As an example:
We define minimum water quality metrics the community agrees to maintain such as turbidity and dissolved solids. If water quality doesn't meet the minimum standard there's a penalty imposed on the city's waste water treatment facility. Consequently, the waste water treatment facility will increase the cost of water services. The money collected from the penalty must be redistributed to areas in the community that are most responsible for the water pollution. So, if dissolved solids is too high because farmers aren't using cover crops in the winter to prevent erosion the money can pay for a farmer's cover crops.

He stayed in the lane of his party's predefined political narrative.

text:
Burning of fossil fuels "causes" global warming and global warming "causes" the release of greenhouse gasses. Both are true. A 0.2 increase over 100 years is outrageously fast in geologic time scales, and geologic time scales are all we have to go on when interpreting the effects of climate change. So given the data we have to work with, climate change is a problem.


I think I would have answered this girl in two ways: 
First, my "solution" to climate change is nuclear power. I firmly believe that nuclear power is as close to a panacea we'll ever find, doubly so if we ever get nuclear fusion working. Considering that all the nuclear waste from all of earth's power plants ever will fit inside a basketball court (or something like that, it's not much) I think disposal isn't really a big deal. 
Secondly, the life on earth has rebounded from mass extinctions that occurred over shorter periods of time than anything warned about by the left today. Near as we can tell, none of those previous extinction events fell upon sapient life. We have technology, we are inventive and we are already outgrowing the limitations of our natural world. If the planet becomes uninhabitable in the next few hundred years, yeah, we're probably going to go extinct. But I genuinely don't think it'll take much more time than that to where our technology will make our species capable of surviving catastrophies. Thus, the challenge for the environmentalist movement is to convince me that climate change presents an existential threat to life on our planet within the next few hundred years. If they can, I'm all for a solution...see my first answer above.

text:
PLEASE BE ADVISED: there is NO DIRECT PHYSICAL EVIDENCE which supports the notion of man-made global warming. FULL STOP. ALL such statements to the contrary are based not on any empirical evidence; rather, such are based on SPECULATIVE and inaccurate computer models; and, yes, these IPCC models HAVE DEMONSTRATED, time and again, to be INACCURATE in predicting future global temps. REPEAT: there is NO DIRECT PHYSICAL EVIDENCE.

Note further: there are MANY scientists who believe that there is a GREATER PROBABILITY that our planet will sooner be entering an extended period of COOLING rather than WARMING, and, that it is NOT the result of increased CO2 values; man-made or otherwise.

For those examining the USA, the observation of this cooling, in the most general terms, is obvious: our land temp records, which are the most comprehensive in the world --- this is simply a fact, where such records were kept since the late 19th century --- show, without doubt, that our warmest period encountered during this entire interval [1895-present], was during the "Dust Bowl" days of the later 1930s and early 1940s. The ALL-TIME USA record temp [134-degree, Death Valley, CA] was recorded in 1937.

Since that time, our USA temperatures --- that is, the original temp readings and not those which have been "massaged" --- have been following a gradual COOLING trend.

Note: NOAA and NASA have been publishing contrary temperature messages --- that we are NOW experiencing our "hottest" years and that the trend is in the direction of continued warming --- however, what they do not tell us is that, in order to derive these "warming trends", they have been using fraudulent techniques to manipulate the original temperature values.

Please help end the global scam and spread this message.

text:
@Roger didit  Molten Salt Reactors (MSR) are the future of nuclear energy.  They cost 1/5th as much to build and operate as current reactors do.  They produce 1/5th the nuclear waste, and the waste only has to be shelved for 2-300 years tops as opposed to conventional reactor waste taking hundreds of thousands of years.  They're about 1/8th the size of current reactors, and they don't operate water under pressure (which is why current reactors are so fakoking dangerous).   MSR nuclear plants can NEVER melt down, they can NEVER explode like current nuclear reactors do. 

MSR's are walk away proof.  You could literally start the MSR plant, and all employees could walk away and if anything ever happened in the reactor chamber, the plant would shut itself down without human intervention.

Progressives like to employ hyperbole in an effort to elicit emotional responses from people so that they can justify the tax they say can "fix" whatever it is that they're being hyperbolic about. 

So people like Al Gore make hyperbolic claims, 20 years ago, that NYC would soon be under water... AOC makes the hyperbolic claim that the world will end in 12 years. 

That being said, they aren't wrong about man made climate change, they're just wrong on the timelines involved. 

Man made climate change is very real, but we can fix it if we just spin up 1000's of MSR nuclear reactors.

For all of the glacial and interglacial periods that have taken place over the last two million years or so, leading into today, CO2 levels have vacillated between 190 ppm to around 280 ppm. 

Like clockwork. 

When we came out of the last glacial period, CO2 was around 200 ppm. 

In 1860, CO2 levels were measured at around 260 ppm. 

Today, we're at over 410 ppm. 

130 ppm higher than where we should be is not an insignificant amount. 

The earth's atmosphere is like the canvas that the sun's energy gets painted upon. 

The last time the earth had CO2 levels equal to what we have today, the earth's ocean levels were 60 feet higher than they are today.

Here is how the earth's climate gets generated.

Energy from the sun crosses the void between earth and sun.  That energy heats the surface of the earth which radiates the heat up into the atmosphere.  The heat gets trapped by the greenhouse gases that are present in the atmosphere as it begins it's process of rising through the atmosphere to eventually radiate off into space.

Greenhouse gases absorb and retain heat.  This was proved over a century and a half ago by John Tyndall.  It's just a fact of physics that if you increase the density of greenhouse gases in the earth's atmosphere, like we are doing today using copious amounts of fossil fuels as a source of energy, you are going to increase the amount of absorption and retention of heat within the earth's atmosphere thus warming the climate.

text:
Knowles is exactly right here. This is my beef with the ongoing, and quite nonsensical and incompatible political mixing in this debate. Conservatives, at least the ones I know who have standard knowledge about the environment and can reasonably speak to it honestly and civily, are largely for ensuring the environment is taken care of. What we aren't for is the political, cultish and corrupt nonsense that goes along with activist environmentalists. Knowles said it best that we don't believe man serves nature; that is a religion/cult of these folks and cannot be taken seriously in any conversation. You can't pretend that imposing your will on anyone and our government with force, in regards to the environment specifically, is a reasonable proposal that anyone would listen to. It's even worse because then they say we can't ask questions, we can't express concerns, we can't make conclusions or appeals because of this flimsy appeal to certifications and credentials that is wholly arbitrary and in fact unscientific. I believe politics and working on environmental solutions are not in any way compatible. They shouldn't even be in the same room. I was just having an argument with an environmentalist cult member(aka a YouTube comment section environmentalist) who believed straws in the ocean and in turtles noses, both of which are anecdotal and nuanced, somehow warrants big government statist policies. This is among other fraudulent theories and underlying premises that they don't want you challenge at all, even when facts, examinations, basic scrutiny, or statistics debunks them. 
Hopefully we can get past the canards, obfuscations, hysteria, existential threats, and incoherence, and actually be productive on all fronts.

If anything it good to have high CO2 levels because plants grow very well in that environment. It's the bad gases in the greenhouse gases we need to try and fix. Which we gradually are. Cars are producing less and less of the bad green house gases. And power company's are releasing less and less as well (at least here in the US, other countries are another thing). So the earth may actually go up in temperature anyway even if we get rid of all the bad green house gasses. And if we are worried about animals and plans going extinct who cares. Of all the animals and plants that ever existed on this planet a good 99% of them are extinct. That's how the earth works. Did we humans kill off all those ? No we didn't.The natural cycle of the earth did. Mother nature did. At least 2+million have gone extinct. But they only estimate 500 in the last decade are because of humans. That's 0.025% if using the 2M number. May be even less of a % if the number of extinct is higher.

text:
If only she was more articulate about hte topic...  She's not wrong about man made climate change, she's just not very well versed in it to argue the point.  It's simple.

John Tyndall proved, over a century and a half ago, that greenhouse gases absorb and retain heat (CO2 being the greenhouse gas we humans are pumping out in greater and greater degrees each year).

Thus

Svante August Arrhenius correctly theorized, at the turn of the last century, that if you increase the density of greenhouse gases in the earth's atmosphere, which we humans are definitely doing today with the use of fossil fuels, you are going to increase the amount of absorption and retention of heat within the earth's atmosphere thus warming the climate.

text:
I think we know exactly what the catastrophe being warned about is: sea level rise, unpredictable changes in ocean and wind currents, unpredictable and severe weather, ocean acidification, ecosystem collapse, melting permafrost releasing trapped methane deposits, etc. I don't think it's helpful to pretend to not know what the claims are when we hear them all the time.

And while an inconvenient truth hasn't aged well, and the fact that there's a lot of alarmism and dogma surrounding the issue, its still reasonable to take the issue of climate change seriously. Remember climate change wasn't a partisan issue until the 2000 Bush/Gore election, Regan considered it an issue worth addressing.

The problem is that trying to address a global problem will naturally lend itself to a globalist worldview, which of course leads to big government and decisions being made by unaccountable super-national bodies. If conservatives want to win on this issue it would be wise to acknowledge that it is a problem instead of engaging in handwringing and denialism whenever it comes up. I think that this kind of denial only serves to push anyone who cares about it towards the left where they will campaign for top-down regulatory action instead of individualist and local communitarian and free-market solutions to the problem.

text: @J Johnson  that's an interesting way to put it. Tho it does sound like one I'm not exactly a fan of. Let's be honest, does being called a "simulations" sound fulfilling??? Like it gives us a greater understanding??? And if this is a "simulation" then whose the protagonist, like in video games??? Even in simulations, there is a reason and purpose for each and every person here. I'd also like to challenge the idea of "no absolute truths" when gravity, thermodynamics, nuclear science, astrophysics, and other sciences that demand order and solid truths to exist. Even something simple as mathematics needs solid absolute truth to work more often than not. While this is maybe a simulation,(not saying it is, I'm just supposing it is. Think of Plato and his logic system in his laws book) to say that absolute truth is non-existent is foolish. We can't find a triangle, and there fore construct most buildings, without Sine, Cosine and tangent. We can't determine the tensile strength of concrete without a static item, like iron, to compare with. The entire world runs on mathematics, with solid truths all over the place, so I'm family certain that "absolute truths" exist here, even if we are a highly advanced simulation.

text:
@omgwtfbbq  
Well, when it comes to believing in God and the question of life on other planets; there really isn't any relationship between the two. 
Think about it, if there is a God (and there is) he either created life on other planets or he didn't. He never specifically mentioned it so it's up in the air. 
If we were to suppose that the universe came from nothing, either life arose on other planets or it didn't. We haven't seen it yet so it's up in the air. 

The two questions really have very little of anything to do with one another. Existence of aliens doesn't exclude the existence of God (and more specifically doesn't exclude the Christian God), and existence of God doesn't exclude aliens. We are left with an identical unknown regarding life on other planets regardless of our theological positions. It's an interesting thought imo.

text:
J Johnson man... i dont even know where to begin... i read some of your conversations here (not all since there are so many), so i dont know how much you already disscused this with other but i would still like to engage in conversation with you.

First of all so you get some background, I'm a chatolic person that loves science (studied it quite a bit in free time, high school, competitions...) and now am a medicine student. Now there are just some stuf i would like to discuss with you
Firstly, about that hollow earth: well it's true we havent dig all the way to the centre and cant know what would find there although if you knew about any scientific principle about gravity and mass, and how things interact in space you would know that the deeper you would go the more dense mass you would find as the mass of the earth is centered in the centre which creates pressure, if hollow however the sphere would just collapse. I know the theories about unknown seem interesting amd intruiging and it's fine to fantasise about them but they just wouldnt work in real life.
Then the next thing (there are so many i dont even knoe what i want to talk about, so i hope we can have further disscusions)  about your anwser to gravity as some perception. Well yes ofcourse things are percived through our brain and all rhat you were talking about, but thinking we live in some simulation just gives me idea you watch too many movies like the matrix and have a great imagination ( not meant as an insult). I study the human body at university and how it functiones and i can tell you its really interesting so give it a try (some reading in free time that is) you might see things in different way then. I had a feeling a had to tell you something about this topic since i'm not sure i understand and agree whit what you sad but i dont know what else to say for now so maybe we can disscus this further later.
Then the fact you called science a faith... I'm chatolic cristian and that is my faith, but science i see as facts of this world. And don't get me wrong, the two can get hand in hand perfectly. Nobody claims they know everything, anybody who is into science (doesnt matter which field) knows they only know so much. There is no way you can learn everything we as human kind already know and still there are so many undiscovered things left. But the part that there are no thruths we know for certain and that part about theories you just got wrong. There are things we can prove are real 100%, gravity being one of them. And the theories part, well...
Yes some are just theories. We DONT know everything yet (dont know if we ever will) so some thing we can just assume, beeing the most likely to be true given the information we already have. About big bang, yes its a theory that changed many times and we dont know everything about it, we dont uderstand everything about it, and that is the way it is with that. But saying all theories are just theories and cannot be taken for real thing? That's the part you got wrong. Yes you can give me definition of a word from dictionary but words have different meanings esspecially in different proffesions, fields of science... 
Theories in science arw not meant as possibilities but facts, they are just called theories. Yes some are incomplete but not most of them. We as inteligent beings already understand so many mysteries of this universe, and we know those are facts. 
You bring out interesting topics and its fun and intriguing to engage with a  person with imagination like yours. I hooe we can disscus some topics further, maybe any questions, missunderstandings from my part or even further debating would be nice so hope i hear from you
author: the last invoker

text:
Three questions "science" needs to address: 1) What is the optimum mean temperature of the Earth? This question recognizes that different places will do "better" at different mean earth temperatures, so whatever mean Earth temperature we settle on will necessarily be a compromise. At what temperature does that compromise impact all the places on Earth the least?     2) What harm comes to the overall environment if the temperature varies too far from that optimum?  3) Is there a critical point at which the temperature becomes so damaging to the environment that any repair is not possible, or is the environment self-correcting?
Have a coherent answer to two of those three questions, and I'll listen. Otherwise, go practice your religion in private, and quit annoying me.

text:
-CO2 is not a pollutant. It was never considered a pollutant until global warming theory. It was considered plant food.
-The data you're referring to comes from the Vostok ice core (Petit et al, 1999). Temperature rises ~800 years before the CO2 rises over the last 400,000 years in the ice core record. That estimate has since been revised to closer to 100-200 years, but still shows temperature precedes CO2.
-There is no "catastrophe" yet. There has been no appreciable rise in quantity or severity of storms since 1950. It is entirely theoretical, based on changes to the Gulf Stream or other major air or water currents. This could happen. When it has in the paleoclimate record, rapid and severe climate change has occurred (ex: the Younger Dryas).
-You are correct that the main proponents of this weak theory use it to push sovereign countries to give up control over their economies to international bodies. Their goal is indeed one-world government with socialist economic policy, and they have made no secret of that. The Green New Deal is just the latest iteration of a long line of proposals, all made in the context of gun control/confiscation, wealth transfer, and efforts to secure state control of education, healthcare, energy, banking, and industry. It is, by definition, socialism.

author: Lucas Rodrigues

text: I agree with you on all points; however, the only catastrophe continued warming would bring (assuming our rate for the past 100 years continues until 2100 and so on) is strengthened tropical storms and sea level rise of 0.5 to 2 meters by 2100. In terms of higher latitude weather, it could easily weaken/ become less extreme, as the pressure and temperature gradient between latitudes, would decrease, meaning there would be more stability in the atmosphere. Stability North and South of the tropics is a good thing, as it means less extreme temperature changes and dips in temperature. The only problem is that more stability and less wind shear means tropical storms would be able to form more easily.

We aren’t taught in school how the fossil fuel industry is a resource-creating industry; we are taught that it is shamelessly exploiting dwindling natural resources. ― Alex Epstein, The Moral Case for Fossil Fuels

text: Funny thing is that everyone here thinks I'm liberal when I'm not. Politically, I'm smack dab in the center, leaning right or left on several different issues. More than anything, my goal is to replace my ignorance with knowledge from all perspectives in hopes that doing so will gradually allow me to articulate what I actually stand for and believe in. I did a research project on the conservative stance on climate change (some proposing conservative climate policies https://www.clcouncil.org/mission/) so I wanted to see if Knowles had any of his own ideas for policies he'd support, but he didn't ever get to answering that. I never claim to be an expert. Doesn't matter if I'm speaking to a conservative, liberal, socialist, or a full-on marxist, if there was a gap in the information I was being given, I would push back on it and ask a question...Isn't that the point of attending speaker events like these? Isn't that the whole goal of trying to understanding a position you don't fully get?

author: Context Should Matter

text:
Even if we grant them the argument that the danger of climate change is real, people have no realistic solution.

Im all for less pollution, but nobody has come up with a good way to solve the problem that people are told to worry about.

So far the ideas Ive heard are:
-Banning jet planes
-Spraying sun blocking particles into the atmosphere
-Reducing cattle populations

Even if all first world countries become carbon neutral in the next 50 years, third world countries that rely on coal and fossil fuels will be contributing just as much as ever, how would we justify/accomplish stopping them?

How is anyone going to stop India from polluting air/water?

Furthermore, why isnt anyone proposing adaptation solutions? Why all these cash-grab carbon taxes and scare tactics?

text:
@Kevin Zhou  ..but don't you see how that doesn't line up?  For example the Left says "We should rejoin the Paris Climate Accord" to stop Global warming. I assume you would agree with that.  ..but China, India, and a bunch of other nations who are the TOP POLLUTERS in the world (I believe they are #1 and #2), according to the agreement, don't have to make ANY changes until 2034.  On top of that it calls China a "developing nation" so the US would have to give money to them.   Now if the biggest polluters don't have to make ANY changes for another 14 years, and you say we have 10-12 or it's over?   Isn't that like me making you buy tickets for a concert on June 1st but you can't use them until June 4th but if you don't buy them I call you an evil non supporter of live music?  


So what I am asking is...if you are pushing for a plan which requires massive regulation and massive amounts of dollars being directed where you want while at the same time saying the world will end by the time the plan kicks in??   That can't make sense to you.  Right?


...and keep in mind.  I recall in High School when Al Gore told us 2014 was the end.  Or my mom recalling the front of Time Magazine in the late 70s saying scientist say millions would be dead by the 2000s because of the global freeze that is coming.


....and please keep in mind..when innovation creates energy that is cleaner, more affordable, more access, etc...that is AWESOME and I'm totally for it.  The problem is that people get SO LOCKED IN on just saying "Climate Change" that ANYTHING I want to get from you to gain power or money....all I have do is put the word "Green" in front of it.  So my friend certainly push for us being cleaner and more efficient with energy, but learn to critical too when thing don't like up like a climate plan that doesn't start until after the day you say all is lost.

We have trucks because we need the ability to tow or haul stuff around.  Living out in the country means mending and making your own fences and if you have enough land,  you get taxed- but if you put animals out there,  you get an ag exemption and there's more reason to have a truck . 
Hybrids lol. Did you know that plants that make those including tesla, actually create tons of pollutants? And that compared to actual cars,  your carbon foot print isn't that much smaller? 
Again it sounds like y'all just consume and don't produce anything.

text: @Marked Pagan  with all due respect climate change is absolutely not man made. The hottest temperatures on record were from 950 A.D. to 1250 A.D.. By 1500 we were entering the little ice age. In the United States snow and ice were year round even in the deep south. Now in the 18 th century the earth started to warm up again. The cult of catastrophic climate change is just that, a cult. Catastrophic climate change is a complete hoax.

I was debating this just the other day. When the gentleman exclaimed " we are experiencing the hottest temperatures in history and the rain forest is burning!" I explained to him that the cause of the rain forest burning was man made. Illegal farmers are clearing the land. I also explained that we are not experiencing the hottest temperatures. Between 950 A.D. and 1250 A.D. was known as the Medieval Warm Period, also known as the Medieval Optimum. The earth's temperatures were much higher than they are now. After 1250 the earth started to cool down. From 1500 to about 1730 we experienced the little ice age. With much colder temperatures, in the southern United States we experienced ice and snow year round. Then guess what? The earth started to warm up again. Climate change is cyclical. When our orbit brings us closer to the sun, we warn up. When farther away from the sun, we cool down. Of course once I explained this to him, he immediately started calling me a moron, dumbass and uneducated. I explained to him that just because you disagree with an individual was no reason to insult that individual. He came back with the usual Leftist name calling. Typical.

text:
@Marked Pagan  I'm not trying to be argumentative but I want to respond to your arguments. Some things that aren't taken into consideration when people think about climate change is the ambition for all of us to do better in technology, to do it faster, better and more cheaply than the last guy did. Now if you hamper growth it will inevitably lead to more greenhouse gasses being released into the enviroment. If you limit energy, which is what you do if you turn away from fossil fuels, then people will not have a safe method for heating homes. So you will have people going with out heat. People will not do that, they will cut down more trees and burn those for heat and cooking when the power goes out (this is just a simple example obviously). Also something to consider is that we not only do not have the infrastructure in place for green energy, but also green energy will not even begin to come close to energy needs. First off we can't store the excess energy, we don't have the tech available to do that, so most of your power will be made in the day and in night, well not so much. But lets say we fix the storage problem, then you have to deal with the bird population. You see when you have either wind turbines or solar power, you have this major problem with killing local and migratory bird populations in the area. The turbines slice and dice but the solar literally cooks them in mid flight. They call them shooting stars at those large scale solar facilities out west, because when a bird flies into the heat path created by those solar cells, it literally sets on fire and drops out of the sky. It seems that the best way to control greenhouse emissions is to bring the world out of poverty as when you raise the median income of a given area, one of the natural responses people have is to try to do more for the environment. Also, a big issue too is this idea we can change what is happening. Based on geological data, this is something that happens roughly every 13k years or so. We are at the end of a 13k year cycle. before the end of the last cycle, Egypt was prairie land and the majority of America was under about 2 miles of ice. So the better question is not how to stop it, because that won't happen, the better question is how do we survive it? At least, that's the question I'm always asking. Now all of this aside, I absolutely agree that changes need to be made to help protect the environment. I mean you don't burn down your house because they shut off your water. But we also need to understand that going backwards will cause more harm than good. 

Also, something that always comes to mind with this subject is how the richest among us are the ones to call for change because of the environment when those are the assholes how benefited the most. The jack dorseys, Bill gates, Mark zuckerburgs and Jeff bozos of the world. They literally benefitted from this shit more than anyone and now they want to tell us how we need to do better. I mean fuck all those assholes. Every aspect of their empires are based on fossil fuels and human suffering. It's like the CCP telling other people not to commit human rights violations.

text: I don't see how asking a question and pushing back a bit to really try to understand someone's stance is a bad thing. I feel it might be interesting for you to know that I'm actually not liberal. Politically, I'm smack dab in the center, and I lean right on several issues. I took a course in the sociology of conservatism (taught by a conservative) where I wrote a research paper on the conservative stance on climate change. I was fascinated by the rich history of environmental protection among notable conservatives back in the day. Even today, some are proposing conservative policies to address the risks of climate change (https://www.clcouncil.org/mission/). I wanted to see if Knowles had any of his own ideas for policies he'd support, but he didn't ever get to answering that. Doesn't matter if I'm speaking to a conservative, liberal, socialist, or a full-on marxist, if there was a gap in the information I was being given, I would push back on it and ask a question...Isn't that the point of attending speaker events like these? Isn't that the whole goal of trying to understanding a position you don't fully get?

text:
Well said, I paraphrase, the environment is to serve human beings, and some of us want an environment to sustain human beings and other life. I am opposed to fraudulent environmental causes being used by those in government and industry to control the people. On the flip side, I oppose toxic pollution, for example, carbon monoxide which can poison and kill, but not carbon dioxide, which at atmospheric concentrations does not harm human beings and animals and is consumed by plants.


I disagree that those who claim global warming is real and is man-made don't have predictions of disasters for human beings, they do. It is just that their claims are based on fraud, fraudulent temperature readings, fraudulent computer models, claims of disasters which have not occurred, and blaming nearly everything on global warming without showing cause. There is a lot of hype. Tony Heller is doing a good job showing the fraud.

text:
Francis Tan Your statement is partly false I am sorry. Firstly there is a ton of evidence which backs the climate change is caused by human actions. 
By air pollution the atmosphere thickens which makes it harder for sun energy to be reflected out of our atmosphere which makes the climate warmer. Trees and plankton that use co2 and absorb these to create air get more and more cut of or killed to pollution in the oceans. So if we could plant a hell lot of trees and plants that counter measure these effects we have won partially. 

It gets really tricky when the ice caps melt of because they reflect most of the sun. So what will happen ? There is so much ice that can melt and if you ask scientists how much has already melted you‘ll be shocked. The water level in general will rise quite strongly. 
Ultimately water temperature will get so high that the number and intensity of hurricanes will increase quite strongly so there you have the arguments about consequences as well. 

And there are some things we can do. If it is enough is hard to say but isn’t it worth to be trying so the human kind has a future on earth until the point the whole Milky Way collapses ? 
I don’t claim to know all kind of consequences and parts of these systems but this partial understanding is already enough to realize we have a problem which is existential.

text: Anthropogenic Global Warming is a complete hoax.  Both CO2 and temperatures have been higher in the past.  Atmospheric CO2 does not cause temperature rise - it follows it.  NASA and other government agencies tamper with temperature data to make graphs look one way when the originally recorded data looks another way.  I could go on and on.  The actual science shows that AGW is bullshit.  And anyway ALL the so called “solutions” would not “solve” it anyway.  It’s a way to make socialism/communism palatable to scientifically misinformed people.

author: Wicked Henderson

text: artie lusk I agree that AOC is a moron. The facts are that there is more carbon in the atmosphere than ever before and it has never been this high. That is what the data shows. We know there is a link between GHGs and an increase in global temperatures. We also know that since 1980 the Arctic sea ice in the summer has reduced by 40%. Humans would not have such an impact on the environment if we stopped cutting down vast swathes of the Amazon and other forests. Then I would feel comfortable letting nature take its course but according to leading experts the global animal population has decreased by 60%. This isn’t sustainable.
author: gijones8950

text:
artie lusk exactly. Imagine looking at all the scientific data and still denying that it is true... imagine that. The left don’t know what they are talking about. They really don’t. But then again some right wingers believe in the rapture and all sorts so just because one person is an idiot doesn’t mean that we should dismiss the argument entirely. 

The facts as I have seen them are this: 

There is more carbon dioxide in the atmosphere now than at any other point in recorded history about 800,000 years worth. 

People say about natural cycles due to slight variations in the earth orbit and that is correct but we are at the peak of one of those cycles (and there are about 7 recorded from the biggest ice core we have) and we have exceeded all previous amounts of CO2 in the atmosphere including that cause by volcanic eruptions.

So if you can accept the fact that there is more Greenhouse gas in the atmosphere before, you can accept that the ramifications of that will be the heating of the globe. 

The problem is not that the temperature has changed but that it has changed rapidly. More rapidly than ever before. We have never seen this sort of change and it is alarming. That is the long and the short of it.
author: gijones8950

text:
artie lusk you’re right about AOC. I agree 100%. There are approximately 30 million head of cattle in the US compared to 50 million plains Buffalo 200 years ago. Are we saying that cow farts are different to buffalo farts? No. She is just nuts. She isn’t wrong that methane is a greenhouse gas but she is just a bit cuckoo anyway. 

China isn’t actually going to be a problem as they are so rich now they are focussing heavily on renewables. India, yes but that will leave just the US and India as the world’s biggest polluters. So saying “but China does it” is very short sighted and not actually an argument for anything. Two wrongs don’t make a right. 

Just remember the salient point is the rate of change not the change itself. If the temperature had increased gradually over thousands of years like it has before then that’s fair, but it has been increasing relatively rapidly compared to the rest of the cycle and the only explanation is the industrial revolution that occurred 200 years ago. 

Btw as an aside the actual biggest threat to the human race in terms of climate change (as decided by a global action panel) is not cow farts or CO2 at all. It is CFCs from refrigerators. By comparison is is 16,400 times as warming over 500 years as CO2 is. Some research actually (and quite accurately) suggests that the main cause of global warming is CFCs (the other greenhouse gasses compound the problem after the fact). Correct disposal of old CFC containers is fundamental to the continued survival of the planet as we know it.
